Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
South American valve servers have almost no cheaters of any kind.

This will always be the best "hero" shooter, casual fun environment + comedic in voice acting and game design that are alien to modern games.
No stoic military heros; no heros that couldn't bear ill will against a mosquito; no evil heros of tragic backstory that might be just misunderstood, but instead a bunch of human psycopaths bearing a cartoony levels of hate and love towards each other.
No ultimates to cause a "Q" kitchen sink standoff; only cooldown is running out of loaded ammo; no hero sharing a role with each other; no role-locking yourself; 9 heros with sidegrades will always be more insteresting and balanced than 40+ hero rosters even when there is no real update in a decade.
Not to mention how mechanically deep some tricks can be.
It is a very old game, and still the best in the genre.

Review:
completion:
This game is my 6th favorite game of all time!

It has a lot of things to love.

10/10 exploration and rewards for exploration.
10/10 combat feel and diversity.
10/10 variety of builds.
10/10 graphics and music.
And something I feel the Dark Souls series lacked, a 10/10 story that you get given to you in an understandable narrative BUT you can, additionally, seek more lore through item descriptions and environmental storytelling, which is wonderful.

The only complaint I have about this game is its lack of accessibility settings that are, on purpose, not included. Not even a pause button (though the game can be paused by a secret technique players found). 

I deeply and wholly recommend this game to anyone who has doubts about the Souls series. 
I also recommend this game to anyone else. This is one of those games where there will, at least, be something for you, if not the entire game becoming something you love. :)

Review:
completion:
What can I say, the gameplay is one of the best of any mmo I've ever played, it's a ton of fun, and the depth of combos are fun to learn.  A lot of beautiful dungeons to explore, the raids are a ton of fun and getting better gear feels really good.

That is, it would feel good if it didn't feel so shit.  The 5% chance of getting leveling a weapon up after grinding all day only to be set back and there's NOTHING you can do but wait till tomorrow to try again feels shit.  It makes the game take much longer, I get it, it pads out the content to keep players whittling away until more content comes out, but it sucks, no other way about it.  I put up with it as long as I did because the gameplay, dungeons and raids are top notch and a ton of fun.  But I can only spend 4 hours a day doing the same exact grind over and over again before I burn out. Not even gonna cover how you can just pay hundreds or thousands of dollars to just speed up the gear grind like some dogwater mobile game.

Only play this game if you want to make an mmo your after work part time job.  I want to recommend the game, and it is free so try it out maybe you'll like it but its just too much for me.

completion:
Sadly, another one that couldn't live up to the hype.
In simplest terms, it's Diablo or PoE with way too many unnecessary layers thrown on top (to add "depth") that turn it into a disjointed, disorienting, grindy mess.
The story's the standard savior-of-the-world formula: You're a rookie who finds out you're an ultra-powerful savior from some obscure prophecy and oddly wise, cutesy little alien plant beings help you along the way.
The gameplay is also standard for the genre: Round up clumps of enemies, press the appropriate buttons, and blow them all up with a bunch of pretty lights until you reach a boss...who you blow up with the same pyrotechnics.
It's actually good fun for a little while, until it gets needlessly complicated and you find it necessary to treat it like a second job just to keep up.

Review:
completion:
The 'Meet your Match' update proved even a 9 year old game will succumb to the trend of matchmaking and force players to only play on Publisher servers. 

Instead of encouraging the individual to host their own servers or join others, Valve chooses to take the bandwidth and discourage community servers by filtering traffic. 
Where then players are greeted by bots, unbalanced teams or 10 minute matches that nobody gets to stay in after. The threat of bots is always alive as long as Valve continues to funnel the majority of tf2's playerbase into their own servers, where they do little to no moderation.

Valve should bring back the ability to select teams, in order to keep games balanced. Valve should also bring back the quickplay system. It kept both Valve servers and dedicated community servers populated. And matches within community servers are allowed to go on for hours, meaning you can play on the same map/gamemode to your heart's content.

Tf2, as a software, was developed by Valve, yes. But its very experience was developed by the community FOR the community. Don't let anyone tell you Valve can replicate it through their servers alone.

The gameplay is decent, but the overall gameplay loop may not appeal to everyone. After playing for two years, I reached a point where the endless grind became exhausting (I quit in June 2024). The introduction of Tier 4 felt like a missed opportunity for a fresh start, which could have brought new and returning players onto the same playing field. Unfortunately, it ended up being the same cycle, just with new materials and "upgraded" skills. I understand this is a Korean MMORPG, so grinding is expected, and the game constantly triggers FOMO. However, with the recent change in directors, I hoped Tier 4 would offer a meaningful reset, helping us move past the brutal Tier 3 grind.

The game was fun, but maintaining progress (with alts and farming gold) eventually became overwhelming.

If you're still reading, my advice is simple: enjoy the game, but don‚Äôt let it become a second job. Treat it for what it is.. a game.

6/10

After putting almost 100 hours into Battlefield 2042, I‚Äôve spent most of my time in the Engineer role ‚Äî repairing vehicles, holding objectives, and keeping the team moving under fire. There‚Äôs something satisfying about being the backbone of a squad, making sure our armor stays operational while dishing out damage with launchers and gadgets.

I‚Äôve also leaned into being a taker ‚Äî pushing aggressively to capture points, secure vehicles, and turn the tide of fights. Whether it‚Äôs locking down a sector solo or coordinating with teammates, those moments of chaos and control make the game rewarding.

On top of that, I‚Äôve logged plenty of time in the skies as a pilot. Mastering helicopters and jets has been a huge learning curve, but flying support runs, evading missiles, and delivering precise strikes feels incredible when it all comes together.

Altogether, the experience has been a mix of teamwork, skill, and sheer adrenaline ‚Äî and even after 100 hours, Battlefield 2042 still finds ways to surprise me.

Review:
completion:
I started playing BF games with BF1942, at launch. I know that on Steam, it becomes cool to hate on games that are hated on by others - whether to get rewards or whatever from others. Having seen the reviews for BF2042, I had very low expectations.

But, at $3, and with a Road to BF6 event for free, what was there to loose?

Simply put, I had a lot of fun. I finished the BF6 event, and enjoyed my journey there. After years of patches, and content updates, and changes - the final state of BF2042 is actually a lot of fun. Honestly I enjoyed it more than BF1 or BFV - neither of which did I personally find enjoyable, especially BFV, which has nothing do with WWII.

I especially like the option to just play against AI if you so choose. Sometimes you just want to sit back and relax, and playing against the AI is a great way to do that, especially with others.

On sale, I think there is tremendous value to this game. I enjoyed it and would recommend it. And thats from a BF player who has been here since day 1 that there was a BF.

The potential with this game is very high but I feel like the developers don't really see the problem and are trying to fix issues which aren't the main ones. I know the team has a lack of funding so I am a bigger supporter owning almost every DLC for the game. The new skill system is the first step in the right direction I have seen since the game came out. The next step for the developers is to make the game more arcade like and add cool but stupid features. Stuff like that is what makes Payday what it is. In payday 2 you could bring an explosive crossbow to a heist and dominate with it or you could use a giant spoon and kill cops with it. The point is the game is trying to be too "realistic." The new skill system really helps because it makes not one build the best but it is up to the player to decide what they want to do. I think they should also expand on the overkill weapons because I feel those have a lot of potential as well. The next best way to make the game more "arcade like" is to add stupid but good and funny weapons and playstyles.

Its possible that when you do log into the game you may feel a bit overwhelmed and inundated with all the User Interface prompts and further down the road you will find a really spread and deep system of tasks and quest-lines you can pursue.

The aesthetic components of this game, in combination with a wide and encompassing story allow for a really engaging and exciting experience. This game can be played solo and with friends.

If you love MMO's and love Dungeon crawlers this game will definitely hit the spot and allow you to hit two birds with one stone with your time.

Enjoy!

Its sprawling, meticulously detailed worlds are the perfect stage for a never-ending cycle of quests and microtransactions that make every victory taste just a tad too artificial. Who needs innovative gameplay mechanics when you can revel in the artful repetition of battling mobs and dungeons, all while your wallet slowly empties itself? Truly, Lost Ark is the epitome of modern gaming luxury‚Äîif you have the patience for grind and the deep pockets to fund your pixelated escapades.

- No spoilers

Review:
completion:
This is by far one of the most conflicting feeling reviews I have ever had to make.

I love the idea of this game being great. It has the bones of being a proper successor to Payday 2, HOWEVER it lacks the massive hoard of content and character that Payday 2 has. The overall game feel is much more refined, FPS is massively improved, the graphics look *good*, the game doesn't crash. Overall what they've done is make what looks more like a proof of concept or a tech demo then an actual game compared to Payday 2.

We all knew that due to the massive buildup of DLC and drip feed content in Payday 2 it makes this game look tiny in comparison, but it makes things much harder to justify playing Payday 3 over 2.

I'm only giving it a recommended rating because of the potential. There is a real chance that over time the game improves as more content is added, but right now I'm not sure I'd pay full price for it.

Pros
+Weather system adds a random chaotic element that I enjoyed (Tornadoes in particular were thrilling)
+The vehicle call in system was good at preventing players from wasting time in the re-spawn screen for vehicles
+Great vehicle variety with interesting twists on every form of transport

Cons
-Horrendously clunky and awkward movement/gun-play
-Character designs scream "Modern Audience", completely ruining the Battlefield aesthetic
-Audio is the worst in the series and voiced lines were all cringe inducing

They periodically update earlier regions to ease the grind, but that is only so newer players don't get stuck on useless content that nobody plays anymore. It's still the same mindless grind at the last region, every day the same obligatory 2 bosses and same 2 dungeons.

And the only way to look cool is to buy skins, that is a major sin of gaming for me.

Write a positive Steam user review for the game "ELDEN RING".
Target rating: 9/10.

Guidelines:
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
ELDEN RING is not a game it is a trial of will.
I entered the Lands Between thinking I was an experienced player. I left as someone more patient, more focused and far more humble.
This world does not hold your hand. It does not explain itself. And it certainly does not forgive mistakes. Every step feels dangerous, every victory feels earned. When you die, it never feels unfair it feels deserved.
Combat is deep, precise, and punishing. Every enemy is a lesson. Every boss is a story. Every defeat is training. The music makes each encounter feel legendary, and the art direction turns suffering into beauty.
ELDEN RING rewards curiosity, punishes arrogance, and respects intelligent players.
There is no wasted time here even the struggle has meaning.
After 100+ hours, I'm still discovering new paths, new secrets, and new reasons to keep playing.
If you're looking for a casual, easy experience stay away. But if you want a journey that will stay with you long after the credits roll. Rise, Tarnished. The throne awaits.

The flight controls are also absolutely crap, I couldn't do the optional mission: "Supply Lines..." from Zero because the plane (or RC) just keeps wobbling around in the air, even with a controller there's no chance, I probably got 3 grey hairs more and unfortunately had to skip this mission. Maybe I'm too incompetent, but it was somehow easier in the original.

The best mission in my opinion was: "Test Drive", racing through the city with nitro, super smooth.
